artist: Artist: Utagawa Hiroshige II; Publisher: Fujiokaya Keijirō
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription:
(Describes how much this temple was appreciated by people in Edo although it was located far from the center of Edo. Its power was believed to protect people from bad luck and evil. So many people were coming over here that it looked like a stack from the distanced.)

{Horinouchi Myōhō-ji no Nichiren daishi no zō wo yaku-yoke no miei to shōshite harukani edo wo hanare tari to iedomo reigen ichijirushiki yue wo shojin tōki wo itowazu ayumi wo hakobi, ?????? tōma no gotoshi}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Views of Famous Places in Edo (Edo meishō zue)
title: Myōhō-ji Temple, Horinouchi
